title: Gaming Calculators
description: A collection of tools and calculators for gamers and esports enthusiasts to track performance and improve gameplay.

kd-ratio-calculator.title: K/D Ratio Calculator
kd-ratio-calculator.description: Calculate your Kill/Death ratio for competitive FPS games.

howItWorks.title: How K/D Ratio Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: K/D Ratio = Total Kills / Total Deaths
howItWorks.explanation: The Kill/Death ratio measures your combat effectiveness in FPS games. A ratio above 1.0 means you get more kills than deaths on average.
steps: Enter your total number of kills
Enter your total number of deaths
Optionally enter games played for per-game stats
View your K/D ratio and performance metrics

useCases: Tracking improvement in games like Call of Duty, CS2, or Valorant
seoTips: A K/D of 1.0 means you're breaking even
Professional players often have K/D ratios of 2.0+
K/D alone doesn't measure objective play
Focus on improving rather than comparing to others
Track K/D over time to see real progress
commonMistakes: Obsessing over K/D at the expense of winning
Not tracking games played for context
Comparing K/D across different games
Ignoring objective contributions

faqs.question: What is a good K/D ratio?
faqs.answer: A K/D above 1.0 is above average. Casual players often have 0.8-1.2, while skilled players may have 1.5-2.0+. Pro players can exceed 3.0.

faqs.question: Does K/D matter in ranked play?
faqs.answer: Winning matters more than K/D for ranking up. However, a good K/D usually correlates with winning more gunfights and helping your team.

faqs.question: How can I improve my K/D?
faqs.answer: Focus on positioning, crosshair placement, and game sense. Die less by playing smarter, and practice aim in training modes.

win-rate-calculator.title: Win Rate Calculator
win-rate-calculator.description: Calculate your overall win rate percentage and monitor your progression.

howItWorks.title: How Win Rate Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Win Rate = (Wins / Total Games) × 100%
howItWorks.explanation: Win rate measures your success percentage across all games played. It's the primary metric for ranked progression in most competitive games.
steps: Enter your total number of wins
Enter your total number of losses
View your win rate and games needed for target rates

useCases: Tracking ranked progression in competitive games
seoTips: 50% win rate means you're at your true skill level
Climbing requires sustained win rates above 50%
Small sample sizes can be misleading
Track win rate by role or character for insights
commonMistakes: Drawing conclusions from too few games
Not accounting for different game modes
Ignoring the impact of teammates in team games
Comparing win rates across different ranks

faqs.question: What win rate do I need to climb ranks?
faqs.answer: You need above 50% to climb. A 55% win rate will climb steadily, while 60%+ will climb quickly. Most players stabilize around 50% at their true rank.

faqs.question: Is 50% win rate bad?
faqs.answer: No, 50% means the matchmaking system has found your skill level. You're playing against equally skilled opponents, which is how ranking systems are designed.

faqs.question: How many games for accurate win rate?
faqs.answer: Generally 50-100 games gives a reliable win rate. Fewer games means more variance due to luck or streaks.

kda-calculator.title: KDA Calculator
kda-calculator.description: Calculate Kill/Death/Assist ratio for MOBA and other competitive games.

howItWorks.title: How KDA Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: KDA = (Kills + Assists) / Deaths
howItWorks.explanation: KDA measures your overall contribution in team fights, valuing both kills and assists while penalizing deaths.
steps: View KDA ratio and kill participation

useCases: Evaluating performance in MOBAs like League of Legends or Dota 2
seoTips: Support players often have high assists but low kills
A KDA above 3.0 is generally considered good
Deaths matter most - dying less improves KDA significantly
Kill participation matters more than raw KDA
commonMistakes: Comparing KDA across different roles
Ignoring game context (winning vs losing)
Valuing KDA over objective play
Not considering team composition

faqs.question: What is a good KDA?
faqs.answer: Above 3.0 is good, above 4.0 is excellent. However, this varies by role - supports may have higher KDAs while carries may trade deaths for high-impact plays.

faqs.question: Why include assists in KDA?
faqs.answer: Assists recognize contributions to team fights beyond last-hitting. This makes KDA more fair for support players and teamwork-oriented gameplay.

faqs.question: Is KDA the best performance metric?
faqs.answer: No, KDA doesn't measure objectives, vision, map control, or clutch plays. It's one metric among many for evaluating performance.

xp-calculator.title: XP Calculator
xp-calculator.description: Calculate experience points (XP) needed for the next level in RPG games.

howItWorks.title: How XP Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: XP Needed = Target Level XP - Current XP
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator helps you plan your leveling journey by showing how much experience you need and estimating time to reach your goal.
steps: Enter current XP in the level
View total XP needed and progress

seoTips: Most games use exponential XP curves
Rested XP bonuses can significantly reduce grind time
Higher level content usually gives more XP
Group play often provides XP bonuses
commonMistakes: Assuming linear XP requirements
Not factoring in XP bonuses
Ignoring efficient grinding spots
Burning out from excessive grinding

faqs.question: Why do games use exponential XP curves?
faqs.answer: Exponential curves slow progression at higher levels, extending game content and giving a sense of accomplishment for reaching high levels.

faqs.question: How can I level up faster?
faqs.answer: Use XP boosts, focus on efficient quests/content, group up for bonuses, and utilize rested XP. Research optimal routes for your specific game.

faqs.question: Does level matter in endgame?
faqs.answer: Usually reaching max level is just the start of endgame content. The real progression often comes from gear, skills, or other systems.

level-up-calculator.title: Level Up Calculator
level-up-calculator.description: Calculate time required to reach target level in games.

howItWorks.title: How Level Up Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Time = Total XP Needed / XP Per Hour
howItWorks.explanation: Estimate how long it will take to reach your target level based on your XP earning rate and the game's leveling curve.
steps: Enter your average XP per hour

useCases: Deciding whether to level alt characters
seoTips: Track your actual XP/hour for accurate estimates
Account for breaks and non-grinding time
Different activities have different XP rates
Events often boost XP significantly
commonMistakes: Overestimating sustainable XP rates
Not accounting for scaling XP requirements
Ignoring fatigue and diminishing returns
Forgetting travel and downtime

faqs.question: How do I measure my XP per hour?
faqs.answer: Note your XP at the start and after one hour of focused play. Do this several times for an accurate average.

faqs.question: Why does leveling slow down so much?
faqs.answer: Most games use scaling XP requirements where each level needs more XP than the last. This extends gameplay and makes high levels feel meaningful.

faqs.question: Should I rush to max level?
faqs.answer: Depends on the game. Some games have content at all levels worth experiencing. Others are designed around endgame content at max level.

dps-calculator.title: DPS Calculator
dps-calculator.description: Calculate Damage Per Second (DPS) to maximize your combat efficiency.

howItWorks.title: How DPS Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: DPS = (Base Damage × (1 + Crit Chance × (Crit Multiplier - 1))) × Attack Speed
howItWorks.explanation: DPS calculates your average damage output per second, factoring in base damage, attack speed, and critical hit statistics.

useCases: Comparing weapons and builds in RPGs
seoTips: DPS is just theoretical - actual combat varies
Consider uptime and practical application
Attack speed and crit often scale together
Don't neglect survivability for pure DPS
commonMistakes: Ignoring practical constraints like mana or stamina
Not considering boss mechanics and downtime
Overlooking synergies between stats
Sacrificing too much defense for offense

faqs.question: Is higher DPS always better?
faqs.answer: Not always. Burst damage, survivability, and utility matter too. A dead DPS does zero damage.

faqs.question: How do I increase my DPS?
faqs.answer: Improve any factor in the formula: base damage, attack speed, crit chance, or crit multiplier. Often one stat is more efficient to stack.

faqs.question: Does this account for abilities?
faqs.answer: This calculator covers basic attacks. For games with abilities, total DPS includes ability damage, cooldowns, and rotations.

loot-drop-calculator.title: Loot Drop Calculator
loot-drop-calculator.description: Calculate the probability of obtaining rare loot based on stated drop rates.

howItWorks.title: How Loot Drop Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Success Chance = 1 - (1 - Drop Rate)^Attempts
howItWorks.explanation: Calculate the probability of getting at least one drop after multiple attempts, accounting for the nature of independent probability events.
steps: See attempts needed for desired certainty

useCases: Planning farming sessions for rare items
seoTips: Low drop rates require many more attempts than expected
A 1% drop rate doesn't guarantee success in 100 tries
Bad luck protection exists in some games
Track your actual attempts vs expected
commonMistakes: Thinking 1% means guaranteed in 100 tries
Not understanding independent probability
Rage quitting due to bad RNG streaks
Not factoring in attempt time

faqs.question: Why haven't I gotten the drop after so many tries?
faqs.answer: Each attempt is independent. Even at 95% cumulative chance, 5% of players still won't have the drop. Bad luck happens.

faqs.question: How many attempts for 50% chance?
faqs.answer: For a drop rate of p, you need approximately 0.693/p attempts for 50% cumulative chance. For 1% drop: about 69 attempts.

faqs.question: What is bad luck protection?
faqs.answer: Some games increase drop rates after failed attempts or guarantee drops after a certain number of tries. Check if your game has this.

fps-calculator.title: FPS Calculator
fps-calculator.description: Estimate the expected frames per second (FPS) for your hardware in different games.

howItWorks.title: How FPS Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Frame Time (ms) = 1000 / FPS
howItWorks.explanation: Convert between FPS and frame time to understand performance characteristics and smoothness of gameplay.
steps: See frames per minute and hour

seoTips: 60 FPS is considered smooth for most games
144+ FPS benefits competitive gaming
Frame time consistency matters as much as average FPS
Match FPS to monitor refresh rate when possible
commonMistakes: Only looking at average FPS, not frame times
Ignoring 1% low FPS figures
Running higher FPS than monitor can display
Not considering input lag

faqs.question: What FPS do I need?
faqs.answer: 60 FPS is smooth for casual gaming. 144+ FPS provides advantages in competitive games. Diminishing returns exist above 240 FPS.

faqs.question: Why does frame time matter?
faqs.answer: Consistent frame times feel smoother than high average FPS with spikes. 16.7ms consistent feels better than averaging 10ms with 50ms spikes.

faqs.question: Does higher FPS reduce input lag?
faqs.answer: Yes, higher FPS means more recent frames are displayed, reducing the delay between your input and seeing the result on screen.

fov-calculator.title: FOV Calculator
fov-calculator.description: Determine the optimal Field of View (FOV) based on your monitor size and distance.

howItWorks.title: How FOV Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Conversions between horizontal, vertical, and aspect-ratio-based FOV
howItWorks.explanation: Convert field of view values between different measurement types used by different games, accounting for your monitor's aspect ratio.
steps: Select the FOV type (horizontal or vertical)
View converted FOV values for different systems

useCases: Matching FOV settings across different games
Optimizing for your monitor and seating distance
Reducing motion sickness from wrong FOV
seoTips: Higher FOV sees more but targets appear smaller
90-110 horizontal FOV is common for PC gaming
Console games often use lower FOV defaults
Too high FOV can cause fisheye distortion
commonMistakes: Not knowing if game uses vertical or horizontal FOV
Setting FOV too high causing distortion
Not adjusting FOV when changing monitors
Copying pro settings without understanding why

faqs.question: What FOV should I use?
faqs.answer: Most PC players prefer 90-110 horizontal FOV. Lower if you sit far from the screen, higher if close. Find what feels natural and doesn't cause motion sickness.

faqs.question: Does FOV affect performance?
faqs.answer: Higher FOV renders more of the world, which can slightly reduce FPS. The impact varies by game and is usually minimal.

faqs.question: Why do games use different FOV systems?
faqs.answer: Some use horizontal FOV (based on screen width), others use vertical (based on height). This affects how FOV changes with aspect ratio.

minecraft-calculator.title: Minecraft Calculator
minecraft-calculator.description: A tool to help you calculate resources and complex recipes in the Minecraft world.

howItWorks.title: How Minecraft Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Resource calculations based on stack sizes and crafting recipes
howItWorks.explanation: Calculate building materials, crafting requirements, and optimal mining levels based on Minecraft's game mechanics.
steps: Select calculation type (building, crafting, or ore)
Enter required blocks or select recipe
View materials needed and optimal strategies

seoTips: Diamonds are most common at Y-level -59
Stack size is 64 for most items
Stairs are less material-efficient than slabs
Mining at chunk borders can be efficient
commonMistakes: Mining at wrong Y-levels for target ore
Not accounting for tool durability
Forgetting Fortune III multiplies drops
Underestimating large build requirements

faqs.question: What Y-level is best for diamonds?
faqs.answer: In Minecraft 1.18+, diamonds are most common at Y-level -59. Mining at bedrock level (around -59 to -64) gives the best results.

faqs.question: How many blocks in a stack?
faqs.answer: Most blocks stack to 64. Some items like ender pearls stack to 16, and tools/armor don't stack at all.

faqs.question: How do I calculate for a large build?
faqs.answer: Measure your build dimensions, calculate total blocks needed, then divide by 64 for stacks. Factor in different materials and waste.

fov.title: FOV Calculator
fov.description: Convert Field of View between different types and aspect ratios.

howItWorks.title: How the FOV Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: hFOV = 2 × arctan(tan(vFOV/2) × Aspect Ratio)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator converts field of view values between horizontal and vertical measurements across different aspect ratios. Since games use different FOV systems, this tool helps you maintain consistent visual settings when switching between titles or monitors.

steps.name: Enter FOV Value
steps.text: Input your current field of view setting from your game

steps.name: Select FOV Type
steps.text: Choose whether your game uses horizontal or vertical FOV

steps.name: Choose Aspect Ratio
steps.text: Select your monitor's aspect ratio for accurate conversion

steps.name: View Conversions
steps.text: See equivalent FOV values for different systems and aspect ratios

useCases.title: Cross-Game Consistency
useCases.description: Match your preferred FOV across different games that use different measurement systems

useCases.title: Monitor Upgrades
useCases.description: Calculate new FOV settings when switching to a different aspect ratio monitor

useCases.title: Motion Sickness Prevention
useCases.description: Find the optimal FOV for your setup to reduce discomfort during gameplay

useCases.title: Ultrawide Optimization
useCases.description: Configure correct FOV for 21:9 and 32:9 ultrawide displays

seoTips: Most PC games use horizontal FOV between 90-110 degrees for comfortable play
Console ports often default to lower FOV designed for TV viewing distances
Ultrawide monitors need wider FOV to avoid zoomed-in tunnel vision effect
Your ideal FOV depends on monitor size and viewing distance
commonMistakes: Using the same FOV number across games without checking if they use horizontal or vertical measurement
Setting FOV too high causing extreme fisheye distortion at screen edges
Copying professional player FOV without considering different monitor setups
Not adjusting FOV after changing monitor size or sitting distance

faqs.question: What is the difference between horizontal and vertical FOV?
faqs.answer: Horizontal FOV measures the viewing angle across the screen width, while vertical FOV measures height. The same number means different actual views depending on which system a game uses.

faqs.question: Why do I feel sick at certain FOV settings?
faqs.answer: FOV mismatch between your screen size and viewing distance tricks your brain. Too low FOV on a close monitor or too high FOV on a distant one causes motion sickness.

faqs.question: What FOV do professional players use?
faqs.answer: Most competitive FPS players use 100-110 horizontal FOV. Lower FOV can make targets larger but limits peripheral vision, so optimal settings depend on game and playstyle.

tooltips.fov_type: Select the type of FOV (Horizontal or Vertical)
tooltips.aspect_ratio: Select the aspect ratio of your screen

info.title: About FOV
info.desc: Field of View determines how much of the game world you can see. Different games use different measurement systems (Horizontal, Vertical, 4:3 Base).

dps.title: DPS Calculator
dps.description: Calculate Damage Per Second (DPS) to maximize your combat efficiency.

howItWorks.title: How the DPS Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: DPS = (Base Damage × (1 + Crit Chance × (Crit Multiplier - 1))) × Attack Speed
howItWorks.explanation: DPS (Damage Per Second) is the fundamental metric for measuring offensive output in games. This calculator computes your average sustained damage by factoring in base damage, attack speed, critical hit chance, and critical damage multiplier to give you an accurate picture of your combat effectiveness.

steps.name: Enter Base Damage
steps.text: Input the damage dealt per single hit or attack

steps.name: Set Attack Speed
steps.text: Enter how many attacks you perform per second

steps.name: Add Critical Stats
steps.text: Input your critical hit chance percentage and damage multiplier

steps.name: Review Results
steps.text: See your DPS along with damage per minute and total damage over time

useCases.title: Weapon Comparison
useCases.description: Compare different weapons or gear setups to find the highest damage output for your build

useCases.title: Build Optimization
useCases.description: Determine whether to prioritize attack speed, base damage, or critical stats for maximum DPS

useCases.title: Theorycrafting
useCases.description: Plan optimal character builds before committing resources in RPGs and MMOs

useCases.title: Boss Strategy
useCases.description: Calculate expected time to defeat bosses based on your damage output

seoTips: Balance between base damage and attack speed often yields better DPS than maximizing one stat
Critical chance above 50% makes critical multiplier increasingly valuable
Consider practical uptime - theoretical DPS rarely matches actual combat performance
Factor in buffs, debuffs, and party synergies for accurate raid calculations
commonMistakes: Ignoring attack animation times and cooldowns in DPS calculations
Forgetting that some games have diminishing returns on attack speed
Not accounting for enemy resistances and armor when planning builds
Sacrificing too much survivability for marginal DPS gains

faqs.question: What is a good DPS number?
faqs.answer: DPS requirements vary dramatically between games and content. Compare your DPS to others in the same game and content level rather than looking for universal benchmarks.

faqs.question: Should I prioritize crit chance or crit damage?
faqs.answer: Aim for a balance - generally 1:2 ratio of crit chance to crit damage is efficient. If you have 50% crit chance, 100% crit damage is optimal in most games.

faqs.question: Why is my actual DPS lower than calculated?
faqs.answer: Real combat includes movement, dodging, ability cooldowns, target switching, and mechanics that reduce your effective damage uptime.

dps.damage_tooltip: Average damage dealt per single hit
dps.attack_speed_tooltip: Number of attacks performed in one second
dps.crit_chance_tooltip: Probability of landing a critical hit
dps.crit_multiplier_tooltip: Damage multiplier on critical hits (e.g., 2.0 for 200%)
dps.duration_tooltip: Time period to calculate total damage for
dps.formula_explanation: DPS = (Base Damage * (1 - Crit Chance) + (Base Damage * Crit Multiplier * Crit Chance)) * Attack Speed
dps.use_case_1: Comparing weapons or builds in RPGs/MMOs
dps.error_positive: Damage and Speed must be positive
dps.error_crit_range: Critical Chance must be between 0 and 100

fps.description: Estimate the expected frames per second (FPS) for your hardware in different games.

howItWorks.title: How the FPS Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Frame Time (ms) = 1000 / FPS
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator converts between frames per second (FPS) and frame time in milliseconds. Understanding frame time helps you analyze performance consistency and identify stuttering issues that average FPS alone cannot reveal.

steps.name: Enter FPS Value
steps.text: Input your current or target frames per second

steps.name: View Frame Time
steps.text: See the corresponding frame time in milliseconds

steps.name: Analyze Performance
steps.text: Compare frame times to understand smoothness and input lag

steps.name: Check Extended Stats
steps.text: View frames per minute and hour for benchmarking

useCases.title: Performance Benchmarking
useCases.description: Measure and compare game performance across different settings or hardware configurations

useCases.title: Monitor Matching
useCases.description: Determine if your FPS aligns with your monitor's refresh rate for optimal smoothness

useCases.title: Stutter Analysis
useCases.description: Convert FPS to frame time to identify inconsistent frame pacing issues

useCases.title: Competitive Optimization
useCases.description: Ensure your system delivers the frame rates needed for competitive gaming advantages

seoTips: Frame time consistency matters more than peak FPS for smooth gameplay
60 FPS equals 16.67ms frame time - the baseline for smooth gaming
Competitive esports players typically target 144+ FPS for reduced input lag
V-Sync eliminates screen tearing but adds input lag equal to one frame time
commonMistakes: Only monitoring average FPS while ignoring frame time spikes and 1% lows
Running uncapped FPS much higher than monitor refresh rate without benefit
Assuming higher FPS always means better performance without checking consistency
Not considering that different games have different FPS requirements

faqs.question: Is 60 FPS enough for gaming?
faqs.answer: 60 FPS is smooth for single-player and casual games. Competitive multiplayer benefits from 144+ FPS for lower input lag and smoother motion tracking.

faqs.question: What causes stuttering even at high FPS?
faqs.answer: Stuttering occurs when frame times are inconsistent. You might average 100 FPS but experience hitches if individual frames spike to 50ms or higher.

faqs.question: Does FPS above my monitor refresh rate help?
faqs.answer: Yes, higher FPS reduces input lag even if your monitor cannot display all frames. This matters in competitive games where responsiveness is crucial.

fps.formula_explanation: Frame Time (ms) = 1000 / FPS. Lower frame time means smoother gameplay and less input lag.
fps.use_case_1: To ensure smooth gameplay and responsiveness
fps.use_case_3: To optimize game settings for better visuals or performance
fps.error_positive: FPS must be greater than zero

loot_drop.title: Loot Drop Calculator
loot_drop.description: Calculate the probability of obtaining rare loot based on stated drop rates.

howItWorks.title: How the Loot Drop Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Success Probability = 1 - (1 - Drop Rate)^Attempts
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator uses probability theory to determine your chances of obtaining at least one drop after a given number of attempts. It accounts for the independent nature of each drop attempt, showing you realistic expectations for farming rare items.

steps.name: Enter Drop Rate
steps.text: Input the stated drop percentage for the item you're farming

steps.name: Set Attempts
steps.text: Enter how many times you plan to try or have already attempted

steps.name: View Success Chance
steps.text: See your cumulative probability of getting at least one drop

steps.name: Plan Your Farming
steps.text: Check attempts needed for 95% and 99% confidence levels

useCases.title: Farming Session Planning
useCases.description: Determine how many runs you need to budget for a reasonable chance at rare drops

useCases.title: Expectation Management
useCases.description: Understand that low drop rates require more attempts than intuition suggests

useCases.title: Efficiency Comparison
useCases.description: Compare different farming locations by calculating drops per hour expectations

useCases.title: Bad Luck Verification
useCases.description: Check if your dry streak is statistically unusual or within normal variance

seoTips: A 1% drop rate does not guarantee the item in 100 attempts - you only have 63% chance
For 95% confidence on a 1% drop, you need approximately 300 attempts
Each attempt is independent - previous failures do not increase future chances
Some games have pity systems that increase drop rates after consecutive failures
commonMistakes: Believing that the gambler's fallacy applies - thinking you're 'due' for a drop
Not accounting for time per attempt when calculating farming efficiency
Assuming bad luck protection exists when the game has true random drops
Rage-quitting after statistically normal dry streaks

faqs.question: Why haven't I gotten the drop after double the expected attempts?
faqs.answer: With independent probability, about 13% of players will need more than double the expected attempts. This is normal variance, not broken RNG.

faqs.question: How do I know if a game has bad luck protection?
faqs.answer: Check patch notes, datamined info, or community testing. Games with pity systems usually mention them, though some keep the mechanics hidden.

faqs.question: Should I give up after many failed attempts?
faqs.answer: Past attempts don't affect future odds. Evaluate whether the item is worth more attempts based on your time, not sunk cost from previous tries.

loot_drop.drop_rate_tooltip: Chance of drop per single attempt
loot_drop.attempts_tooltip: How many times you will try
loot_drop.formula_explanation: Probability = 1 - (1 - Drop Rate)^Attempts. This calculates the chance of getting at least one drop.
loot_drop.use_case_1: To manage expectations for farming rare items
loot_drop.use_case_2: To estimate time or resources needed
loot_drop.error_rate_range: Drop rate must be between 0 and 100
loot_drop.error_positive: Attempts must be greater than zero

kda.title: KDA Calculator
kda.description: Calculate Kill/Death/Assist ratio for MOBA and other competitive games.

howItWorks.title: How the KDA Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: KDA = (Kills + Assists) / Deaths
howItWorks.explanation: KDA measures your overall contribution to team fights in MOBA and team-based games. Unlike K/D ratio, KDA credits assists equally with kills, making it a fairer metric for support players and team-oriented gameplay styles.

steps.name: Enter Kills
steps.text: Input your total number of kills across matches

steps.name: Enter Deaths
steps.text: Input your total number of deaths

steps.name: Enter Assists
steps.text: Input your total assists to get full KDA

steps.name: Add Team Stats
steps.text: Optionally enter team kills to see your kill participation percentage

useCases.description: Fairly assess support player contributions where assists matter as much as kills

useCases.description: Track KDA trends over time to measure skill development

seoTips: A KDA of 3.0 or higher is considered good in most MOBA games
Deaths impact KDA more significantly - dying less improves your ratio dramatically
Kill participation percentage often matters more than raw KDA for team contribution
Different roles have different expected KDA ranges - supports may have higher assists but fewer kills
commonMistakes: Comparing KDA between different roles without context
Prioritizing KDA over winning - sometimes deaths are worth it for objectives
Not considering game length and team composition when evaluating KDA
Ignoring kill participation which shows actual team fight involvement

faqs.question: Is KDA or K/D more important?
faqs.answer: KDA is generally more useful in team games as it recognizes assists. K/D matters more in FPS games where individual elimination performance is key.

faqs.question: What KDA should I aim for as a support?
faqs.answer: Supports often have 4.0+ KDA due to high assists and low deaths. Focus on kill participation percentage (60%+) rather than raw KDA.

faqs.question: Why is my KDA good but I'm still losing?
faqs.answer: KDA doesn't measure objective control, vision, map pressure, or shot-calling. High KDA with low impact on objectives leads to losses.

kda.team_kills_tooltip: Total kills by your team (for kill participation)
kda.formula_explanation: KDA = (Kills + Assists) / Deaths. K/D Ratio ignores assists. Kill Participation is your contribution to team kills.
kda.use_case_1: To measure overall performance and impact
kda.use_case_2: To compare stats across different matches
kda.use_case_3: To identify areas for improvement (e.g., reducing deaths)

Slabs give 6 output from 3 blocks - twice as efficient as full blocks for flooring
Iron ore has two spawn peaks: around Y=16 and Y=232
Fortune III can more than triple your diamond yield - always use it for ores
commonMistakes: Using outdated Y-level information from before the 1.18 cave update
Not accounting for Silk Touch vs Fortune when planning ore mining
Forgetting that some blocks like netherrack mine faster than calculated
Underestimating material needs for detailed builds with multiple block types

faqs.question: What changed about ore distribution in 1.18?
faqs.answer: Ores now use triangular distribution patterns with specific Y-level peaks instead of uniform spawning. The world also extends down to Y=-64, creating new optimal mining heights.

faqs.question: Are stairs or slabs more material efficient?
faqs.answer: Slabs are more efficient (3 blocks make 6 slabs). Stairs use 6 blocks for 4 stairs. For pure efficiency, use slabs; stairs are for aesthetics.

faqs.question: How do I calculate materials for a circular build?
faqs.answer: Use the building calculator for the bounding rectangle, then estimate about 78.5% of that for a circle (pi/4). Add extra for the actual pixelated shape.

minecraft_calculator.calculation_type_tooltip: Choose what you want to calculate
minecraft_calculator.formula_explanation: Calculates resources based on stack size (64). Ore chances are based on 1.18+ distribution.
minecraft_calculator.error_positive: Number of blocks must be positive

win_rate.title: Win Rate Calculator
win_rate.description: Calculate your overall win rate percentage and monitor your progression.

howItWorks.title: How the Win Rate Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Win Rate = (Wins / Total Games) × 100%
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines your winning percentage across all games played. Win rate is the primary metric for measuring success in ranked competitive games and helps you understand where you stand relative to the matchmaking system.

steps.name: Enter Wins
steps.text: Input your total number of victories

steps.name: Enter Losses
steps.text: Input your total number of defeats

steps.name: Add Draws
steps.text: Optionally include draws if your game has them

steps.name: Review Statistics
steps.text: See your win rate and games needed to reach target percentages

useCases.title: Ranked Progression
useCases.description: Track your win rate to understand your climbing potential in ranked modes

useCases.title: Goal Setting
useCases.description: Calculate how many wins you need to reach a target win rate percentage

useCases.title: Character Analysis
useCases.description: Compare win rates across different characters or champions to find your best picks

useCases.title: Session Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor daily or weekly win rates to identify performance patterns

seoTips: A 50% win rate means the matchmaking has found your true skill level
You need sustained 55%+ win rate to climb ranks meaningfully
Win rate stabilizes after approximately 100 games at a given rank
Duo queuing can affect win rate - track solo and party stats separately
commonMistakes: Drawing conclusions from too small a sample size (less than 30 games)
Not separating win rates by game mode or character
Comparing win rates across different ranks or skill levels
Ignoring external factors like time of day or patch changes

faqs.question: What win rate do I need to climb?
faqs.answer: Above 50% will result in climbing over time. 55% is steady progress, 60%+ is fast climbing. The exact LP/MMR gained varies by game.

faqs.question: Is 50% win rate bad?
faqs.answer: No, 50% means perfect matchmaking - you're playing against equally skilled opponents. This is the intended stable state at your true rank.

faqs.question: Why is my win rate high but I'm not climbing?
faqs.answer: Check your sample size. Also, some games have hidden MMR that may differ from displayed rank, affecting how quickly you visibly climb.

win_rate.formula_explanation: Win Rate = (Wins / Total Games) * 100. Total Games = Wins + Losses + Draws.
win_rate.use_case_1: To gauge your skill level relative to others
win_rate.use_case_2: To track improvement over a season
win_rate.use_case_3: To set realistic goals for climbing ranks
win_rate.error_no_games: Total games must be greater than zero

xp.title: XP Calculator
xp.description: Calculate experience points (XP) needed for the next level in RPG games.

howItWorks.title: How the XP Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: XP Remaining = (Target Level - Current Level) × XP Per Level - Current XP
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator helps you plan your leveling journey by determining how much experience you need to reach your goal. It works with linear XP systems and provides estimates for time and effort required.

steps.name: Enter Current Level
steps.text: Input your character's current level

steps.name: Enter Current XP
steps.text: Add your progress toward the next level

steps.name: Set Target Level
steps.text: Choose the level you want to reach

steps.name: Configure XP Rate
steps.text: Input the XP required per level in your game

useCases.title: Grinding Planning
useCases.description: Calculate how much XP you need to farm before reaching your target level

useCases.title: Resource Management
useCases.description: Determine how many XP items or boosts you need to consume

useCases.title: Time Estimation
useCases.description: Estimate how long it will take to reach max level at your current rate

useCases.title: Efficiency Comparison
useCases.description: Compare different leveling methods by their XP yield

seoTips: Most modern games use exponential XP curves - this calculator uses linear approximation
XP boosters and events can cut grinding time by 50% or more
Rested XP in many MMOs doubles XP gain for a limited amount
Higher level content typically gives proportionally more XP
commonMistakes: Assuming all games use linear XP requirements between levels
Not accounting for XP bonuses from gear, buffs, or group play
Burning out by grinding too intensively without breaks
Ignoring story content that often provides significant XP

faqs.question: Why does leveling get slower at higher levels?
faqs.answer: Most games use exponential XP curves where each level requires more XP than the last. This extends game content and makes high levels feel like achievements.

faqs.question: How can I level up faster?
faqs.answer: Use XP boosts, complete high-reward content, group up for bonuses, take advantage of events, and use rested XP systems if available.

faqs.question: Should I rush to max level?
faqs.answer: Depends on the game. Some games focus on endgame content at max level, while others have meaningful content at every level. Consider what content interests you.

xp.current_level_tooltip: Your current level in the game
xp.current_xp_tooltip: Experience points you currently have in this level
xp.xp_per_level_tooltip: Average or fixed XP needed per level (if constant)
xp.formula_explanation: This calculator uses a simplified linear model: Total XP = Levels to Gain * XP per Level. Many games use exponential curves.
xp.use_case_2: Estimating time to reach level cap
xp.error_positive: Levels and XP must be positive
xp.error_target_higher: Target level must be higher than current level

kd_ratio.title: K/D Ratio Calculator
kd_ratio.description: Calculate your Kill/Death ratio for competitive FPS games and track your performance over time.

howItWorks.title: How the K/D Ratio Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: K/D Ratio = Total Kills / Total Deaths
howItWorks.explanation: The Kill/Death ratio is the primary individual performance metric in FPS games. It measures how many enemies you eliminate for each time you die, providing insight into your combat effectiveness and survival skills.

steps.name: Enter Total Kills
steps.text: Input your cumulative kills across all matches

steps.name: Enter Total Deaths
steps.text: Input your cumulative deaths across all matches

steps.name: Add Games Played
steps.text: Optionally enter game count for per-match averages

steps.name: Analyze Performance
steps.text: Review your K/D ratio and efficiency metrics

useCases.title: FPS Performance Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor your combat effectiveness in games like Call of Duty, CS2, Valorant, and Apex Legends

useCases.title: Improvement Measurement
useCases.description: Track K/D over time to see if your gameplay is improving

useCases.title: Loadout Comparison
useCases.description: Compare your K/D with different weapons, classes, or playstyles

useCases.title: Goal Setting
useCases.description: Set realistic K/D improvement targets based on current performance

seoTips: A K/D of 1.0 means you break even - one kill per death
Average players typically have K/D between 0.8 and 1.2
Professional players often maintain K/D above 2.0
K/D improves faster by dying less than by getting more kills
commonMistakes: Obsessing over K/D at the expense of objective play and winning
Comparing K/D across different games with different mechanics
Not considering that K/D varies by game mode and map
Playing too passively to protect K/D instead of making impactful plays

faqs.question: What is a good K/D ratio?
faqs.answer: Above 1.0 is above average. 1.5+ is good, 2.0+ is excellent. However, context matters - aggressive objective play may lower K/D while still winning games.

faqs.question: How can I improve my K/D?
faqs.answer: Focus on positioning, crosshair placement, map knowledge, and game sense. Dying less is often easier than getting more kills. Use aim trainers and review your deaths.

faqs.question: Does K/D affect matchmaking?
faqs.answer: Most games use MMR/Elo systems based on wins, not K/D. However, high K/D usually correlates with winning more gunfights and thus winning more games.

kd_ratio.kills_tooltip: Total number of kills across all games
kd_ratio.deaths_tooltip: Total number of deaths across all games
kd_ratio.games_tooltip: Number of games played (for calculating averages)
kd_ratio.info_description: The Kill/Death ratio is a key performance metric in competitive FPS games. A K/D above 1.0 means you get more kills than deaths on average.
kd_ratio.use_case_1: Tracking improvement in FPS games like Call of Duty or CS2
kd_ratio.use_case_2: Comparing performance across different gaming sessions
kd_ratio.use_case_3: Setting goals for competitive play and ranking up
kd_ratio.formula_explanation: K/D Ratio = Total Kills / Total Deaths. If deaths are zero, the ratio equals the number of kills (perfect ratio).

level_up.title: Level Up Calculator
level_up.description: Calculate the time required to reach your target level in RPG and MMO games.

howItWorks.title: How the Level Up Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Time = Total XP Required / XP Per Hour
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates how long it will take to reach your target level based on your XP earning rate and the game's leveling curve. It accounts for scaling XP requirements that increase with each level.

steps.name: Enter Current Level
steps.text: Input your starting level for the calculation

steps.name: Set Target Level
steps.text: Choose the level you want to reach

steps.name: Input XP Per Hour
steps.text: Enter your average experience points earned per hour

steps.name: Configure Scaling
steps.text: Set base XP per level and scaling factor for accuracy

useCases.title: Session Planning
useCases.description: Determine how many gaming sessions you need to reach a milestone level

useCases.title: Activity Comparison
useCases.description: Compare different activities by calculating which levels you fastest

useCases.title: Alt Character Planning
useCases.description: Decide if leveling an alternate character is worth the time investment

useCases.title: Event Optimization
useCases.description: Calculate how much you can level during limited-time XP boost events

seoTips: Track your actual XP per hour over multiple sessions for accurate estimates
XP events can double or triple your leveling speed - plan around them
Most games have natural breakpoints where XP requirements jump significantly
Group content often provides better XP per hour than solo play
commonMistakes: Overestimating sustainable XP rates by measuring only peak efficiency
Not accounting for breaks, inventory management, and travel time
Forgetting that XP requirements often scale exponentially, not linearly
Ignoring fatigue - long sessions often have diminishing XP per hour

faqs.question: How do I measure my XP per hour accurately?
faqs.answer: Note your XP at the start of a session and after one hour of normal play. Repeat several times and average the results for reliability.

faqs.question: Why is the later leveling so much slower?
faqs.answer: Most games use exponential scaling where each level needs significantly more XP. A level 90-91 might need 10x the XP of level 10-11.

faqs.question: Is it better to grind or do quests?
faqs.answer: Usually quests are faster for first-time leveling. Pure grinding becomes efficient when you know optimal spots and have overpowered gear for the content.

level_up.current_level_tooltip: Your current level in the game
level_up.target_level_tooltip: The level you want to reach
level_up.xp_per_hour_tooltip: Average experience points earned per hour of gameplay
level_up.xp_per_level_tooltip: Base experience points required to level up once
level_up.scaling_factor_tooltip: How much XP requirement increases per level (1.0 = no scaling, 1.1 = 10% increase)
level_up.error_target_higher: Target level must be higher than current level
level_up.info_description: This calculator helps you estimate the time needed to reach your target level based on your XP earning rate and the game's leveling curve.
level_up.use_cases_title: When to Use Level Up Calculator?
level_up.use_case_2: Estimating time investment for reaching endgame content
level_up.use_case_3: Comparing leveling efficiency between different activities
level_up.formula_explanation: Total XP = Sum of (Base XP * Scaling Factor^Level) for each level. Time = Total XP / XP Per Hour.
